Sorry to restart my previous line of questioning (and keep asking very
basi=
c questions), but I was just reading into novelty search, and I'm
wondering=
 how this applies to discontinuity/fractured problem domains.
Searching thr=
ough the user group archives I didn't find any specific
mention of the appl=
ication of novelty search to complex problems with
the discontinuity/fractu=
red domain characteristics.

I understand the benefit of novelty search in =
areas with "deceptive"
stepping stones towards a better solution, where fit=
ness-neat can get
stuck in a local maxima solution (the maze example was pa=
rticularly
helpful).

Does novelty search work better in problems with disc=
ontinuity?

From what I've read, many complex/interesting problems run into=

discontinuity, and standard fitness-neat performs poorly, but I also
just =
watched Ken's talk on novelty search, and he mentioned that most
complex pr=
oblems also run into deception issues.

On Fri, Mar 25, 2011 at 12:55 PM, C=
olin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
> On 25 March 2011 12:51, Drew K=
irkpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@...> wrote:
>>
>> Just curious as I've b=
een thinking about this a bit lately (I'm new to NEAT stuff), as it
>> seem=
s that the micro mutations you talk about, if I'm=A0interpreting=A0papers r=
ight, is one of
>> the reasons standard NEAT doesn't handle fractured domai=
n problems well. As you
>> say, it can't "get there from here". It can't bu=
ild enough structure and optimize it's
>> performance to find a better solu=
tion before that species dies out.
>
> Actually "fractured domains" wasn't =
a term I was aware of, however I
> just read this:
>
> =A0 Evolving Neural =
Networks for Fractured Domains (2008), Nate Kohl
> and Risto Miikkulainen.
=
> =A0 http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/kohl.gecco08.pdf
>
> So frac=
tured domains =3D discontinuity. And yes I would say that's
> definitely a =
major problem with NEAT (not sure about HyperNEAT). I'm
> interested in the=
ir use of radial basis functions, which is something
> that has been mentio=
ned before on this group but not something that
> I've looked into deeply.
=
>
>> Is this the problem you're looking to address here? Or just a method o=
f escaping a local
>> maxima in fitness by allowing more radical adjustment=
s/growth to network topologies in
>> general?
>
> Well it's essentially the=
 same thing if discontinuity is the reason
> you're stuck - which is very o=
ften the case I would say. Complex
> fitness lanscapes are almsot by defini=
tion 'fractured' (As an exercise
> try and think up a complex landscape/dom=
ain that isnlt fractured).
>
>> One thing I was wondering about, and I have=
n't poked around to see if anyone has done
>> some research into, is fiddli=
ng with the species die-off parameter. I was thinking it might
>> be worth =
trying (if someone hasn't done it yet), is to remove the species die off if=
-hasn't-
>> improved-in X generations bit if no species fitness has improve=
d in some specified
>> amount of generations.
>
> I wouldn't expect this to=
 be a major issue where we are right now. If
> a species hasn't improved in=
 a long time then it's probability of
> improving in a further equally long=
 time is low. Evolutionary
> techniques constarined by computing resources =
are always a
> probabilities game - you try and spend your limited CPU time=
 searching
> the areas of the space that have the highest probabilities of =
yielding
> good solutions. This same argument sort of applies to the idea o=
f
> increasing populations - from one perspective the size of the
> populat=
ion is irrelevant as you can only evaluate some fixed number of
> genomes p=
er unit of time. The main effect of pop size is thus to
> provide a broader=
 genetic base to drive genetic crossover and to keep
> an as diverse as pos=
sible population of search points across the
> fitness landscape.
>
>
>> I =
think if you've sat with the same "champion" for a large number of generati=
ons, it could
>> be worthwhile to do something radical, like greatly increa=
se mutations,
>
> Agreed. Just generally - if a search is stuck then 'do so=
mething else'
> would seem to be good advice :)
>
>
>> I'm sure someone has=
 toyed with this at some point. I can always use another couple
>> hundred =
of pages of papers/dissertations to add to my "to-be-read" pile going into =
my
>> thesis :)
>
>
> I think others have played with dynamic mutation rate=
. The problem I
> think is that there may not be any easy routes out of a l=
ocal maxima,
> increasing mutations will sample points a little further out=
 than
> before but it's potentially clutching at straws in many cases. The
=
> other way of looking at it is that the encoding space or the fitness
> la=
ndscape (sort of teh same thing) could be changed such that there
> are eas=
ier routes to the good solutions - that's essentially what the
> radial bas=
is function paper above is doing - your nets can;' get there
> from here, s=
o use a different type of net.
>
> Colin
>
